Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Mechanisms of Emergent Swarm Behavior: Simulation Models vs. Whirligig Experiments.
Award.AbstractNarration: Birds, fish, insects, and humans join groups to avoid predators, gather food, and move long distances. The movement rules of these individuals are remarkably similar between species, as are the emergent group patterns. Two principle questions about emergent patterns will be addressed by this project: 1) how do individual differences (size, gender, leadership) influence a group's speed and turning?, and 2) how do groups interact with solid structures? Techniques to answer these questions include: controlled behavioral studies of marked insect groups; studies mixing real and robotic insects; and mathematical simulation models. Projected results include understanding how: 1) panic responses can spread through a crowd based on motions of only several individuals, and 2) leadership, diversity, and the shape of an exit influences escape rates of panicked groups. Other applied outcomes from the research may include the modeling and control of: geese flocks near airports, humans leaving buildings, military robots, and migrating groups of cancer cells. Tools developed during the research, such as the group simulation model, robotic insects, and automatic tracking system, will be detailed in primary literature articles and/or made available on the internet. As well as the primary knowledge resulting from this cutting-edge interdisciplinary work, the project will train and support nine undergraduate students, preparing them to enter graduate school and become the next generation of scientists ready to decipher the behaviors of animal groups moving through our world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Swarms, flocks, herds, and crowds of people react in remarkably similar ways. Regardless of species, individuals that have evolved to stay together to avoid danger develop similar movement rules. Therefore, the grouping rules of one species can be identified, generalized, and then applied to another species. Simulation models based on these rules can be used to predict the behavior of animals responding to: imminent danger, physical obstructions, and leadership within the group. We used water insects (Gyrinidae: Dineutes) to develop rules of swarm movement and to test how disturbances in these default rules influence emergent swarm behaviors. To do this, we developed methods for filming and tracking the insects, statistically analyzing this movement data, and simulating their behavior. We also developed a robotic insect that interacts with live swarms so that we could test the influence of leadership on the group. Some of our major findings thus far include: 1) only a small percentage (15%) of the group needs to see a predator for a full-group response to develop (called a flash expansion); 2) during flash expansion individuals rarely collide with one another and they move predominantly away from the center of a group; 3) antennae that monitor surface water waves are more important than eyesight to the development of a flash expansion. Useful applications of our results include: 1) development of new tools for studying groups of any species; 2) understanding how bird flocks move around airports and skyscrapers; 3) control of migrating food and pest species such as fish schools and locust swarms; 4) control of groups of mechanical drones for commercial or defense purposes; 5) architectural design of buildings that may reduce human casualties during panicked escape. The grant provided training for 11 undergraduate students as well as support for 32 research presentations and 5 journal papers.
